Introduction

Brain tumors in adults can originate from various cell types and locations in the brain.  They are classified into primary tumors, which originate in the brain itself, and secondary tumors, which metastasize from other parts of the body.  This article focuses on the different types of primary brain tumors in adults.



The general pathophysiology, epidemiology/risk factors, clinical presentation, diagnosis, and management of primary brain tumors are discussed in more detail in a separate dedicated article.  The diagnosis and management of brain metastases can be found there as well.

Pathophysiology



Brain tumors can be classified according to their cell type of origin.  The brain is composed of 2 major cell types: neurons and glial cells.  Neurons, which transmit information throughout the brain using electrical signals and chemical messengers, rarely form tumors.  Tumors more commonly originate from glial cells, which significantly outnumber neurons and normally provide support to maintain the health of the nervous system.  There are 3 main types of glial cells:



  • Astrocytes, the most common glial cell, help regulate the environment around neurons, contribute to nutrient exchange, and play a role in maintaining the blood-brain barrier.
  • Oligodendrocytes produce myelin, a fatty substance that insulates nerve fibers and allows for faster signal transmission.
  • Ependymal cells line the ventricles, fluid-filled cavities within the brain and spinal cord and are involved in cerebrospinal fluid production.


Gliomas, one of the most common types of primary brain tumor, originate from these glial cell populations (eg, astrocytomas, oligodendrogliomas, ependymomas).  Glioma classification is complex, and molecular subtyping (eg, IDH [isocitrate dehydrogenase] mutation analysis) is important (eg, IDH mutations associated with prognosis).  Tumors can also arise from the meninges (eg, meningioma) or from other cell types (eg, pituitary gland, pineal gland, embryonic origin).

Adult brain tumors



Commonly encountered adult brain tumors (discussed in this article) include:



  • Glioblastomas (eg, high grade astrocytomas)
  • Oligodendrogliomas
  • Meningiomas
  • Schwannomas
  • Pituitary tumors
  • Primary CNS lymphoma

Pediatric brain tumors



Commonly encountered pediatric brain tumors include:



  • Pilocytic astrocytomas
  • Ependymomas
  • Medulloblastomas
  • Craniopharyngiomas
  • Pineal gland tumors
  • Choroid plexus papillomas


These are discussed in more detail in a separate dedicated article.

Glioblastomas (high-grade astrocytomas)



Glioblastomas (GBMs) are malignant astrocytic tumors and are one of the most common primary cerebral tumors in adults.  A number of characteristic oncogenic mutations are usually present in GBM:



  • More than 95% of cases are associated with the overexpression of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) on the surface of neoplastic cells.  EGFR is a tyrosine-kinase signal transduction system that conducts external growth signals into the nucleus, thereby promoting cellular survival and proliferation; mutations that enhance this pathway (eg, overexpression of EGFR or EGFR-ligand) are associated with uncontrolled cellular proliferation.
  • As part of oncogenesis, many GBMs methylate the CpG region adjacent to the O6-methylguanine-DNA methyltransferase (MGMT) gene, which generates a protein that repairs damaged DNA (eg, converts O6-methylguanine [a naturally occurring alkylation product] back to guanine).  The resultant silencing of the MGMT gene creates a more permissive environment for DNA mutations to drive cancer growth.


Typical characteristics for GBMs include:



  • Location:  They are usually located supratentorially in the cerebral hemispheres (eg, frontal lobe, temporal lobe) and often cross the corpus callosum.
  • Pathology:  GBMs are composed of atypical (eg, pleomorphic, hyperchromatic) astrocytes that often accumulate in columns around regions of necrosis (ie, pseudopalisading) (
    image 1
    ).  The central necrotic areas represent a vascular insult resulting from haphazard tumor growth, with the surviving tumor cells forming columns as they migrate toward the peripheral vasculature.  These tumors also produce high amounts of vascular endothelial growth factor, resulting in microvascular proliferation.  They are usually glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) positive, indicative of glial lineage.  On gross examination, glioblastomas are typically poorly circumscribed lesions with a variegated appearance, often showing areas of necrosis and hemorrhage.
  • Clinical features:  GBMs are typically fast-growing and can cause significant mass effect (frequently with midline shift).  Patients usually present with symptoms of increased intracranial pressure (eg, headache, nausea/vomiting), focal neurologic deficits, and/or seizures that rapidly progress within weeks.
  • Radiological features:  The stiff falx cerebri typically inhibits direct spread of tumors across the midline.  Therefore, for a GBM to cross the midline, it must spread under the falx at the midline.  This leads to a tumor that is narrow at the midline with a wider spread on either side of the narrow midline portion (ie, butterfly appearance (
    image 2
    )).  Because these tumors have newly formed, highly fenestrated vessels, large amounts of vasogenic edema is seen on imaging; in addition, increased blood flow to the edges of the mass results in heterogenous, serpiginous, peripheral contrast enhancement.  Central necrosis (heterogeneous darkness on imaging) occurs because the center of the tumor is hypoxic.


Patients with GBM are usually treated with some combination of surgery, radiation, and chemotherapy.  Because the pathogenesis often involves silencing the MGMT gene, the cells are more susceptible to alkylating chemotherapy, since they cause DNA damage that cannot be effectively repaired without MGMT; therefore, alkylating agents, such as temozolomide, are commonly used as adjunctive agents in the treatment of GBMs.  However, patients with glioblastoma still have a very poor prognosis; most patients die within 2 years of diagnosis.

Low-grade astrocytomas



These tumors also originate from astrocytes, the most abundant glial cell type.  Typical characteristics include:



  • Location:  These tumors can arise anywhere in the central nervous system but typically occur in the cerebral hemispheres.
  • Pathology:  Microscopic examination frequently reveals a well-circumscribed tumor containing bipolar astrocytes with ovoid nuclei and hair-like (ie, piloid) processes.  These processes contain GFAP, indicative of glial lineage.  Proteinaceous, eosinophilic, cytoplasmic inclusions with a corkscrew appearance (ie, Rosenthal fibers) and eosinophilic granular bodies (thought to be derived from lysosomes) are also often present.
  • Clinical features:  Low-grade astrocytomas may present with subtle symptoms like headaches, seizures, or slowly progressive (eg, over months to years) focal neurological deficits.
  • Radiological features:  On MRI, low-grade astrocytomas often appear as a hyperintense lesion (on T2/FLAIR sequences) that is not contrast enhancing.

Oligodendrogliomas



Oligodendrogliomas arise from oligodendrocytes, cells that produce the myelin sheath insulating nerve fibers and therefore typically involve white matter of the cerebral hemispheres.  These tumors are typically slow-growing but can become malignant.



  • Location:  Oligodendrogliomas can arise anywhere in the white matter, but occur usually in the cerebral hemispheres, often in the frontal lobe.
  • Pathology:  Under light microscopy, tumor cells have a "fried egg" appearance, with round nuclei surrounded by a halo of clear cytoplasm, and are often present within a network of branching capillaries and microcalcifications (
    image 3
    ).
  • Clinical features:  Similar to low-grade astrocytomas, oligodendrogliomas may present with an insidious onset of symptoms.  They frequently present with focal seizures.
  • Radiological features:  Oligodendrogliomas often appear as heterogeneously contrast-enhancing lesions without clear borders on MRI (
    image 4
    ); on CT scan, calcifications are often noted as well (
    image 5
    ).

Meningiomas



These are benign tumors arising from the meningothelial cells of the arachnoid mater.  They are the most common intracranial tumors overall.  Meningiomas are slow-growing, benign tumors; more than two-thirds do not grow, even after several years.  They are most commonly found in middle-aged to elderly women (eg, age >35).  Exposure to ionizing radiation and genetic disorders such as neurofibromatosis 2 (NF2)â€“related schwannomatosis are additional risk factors for developing meningioma.



  • Location:  Meningiomas are often located at a dural reflection, in the falcine, parasagittal, or lateral convexity regions of the brain.
  • Pathology:  Histology shows syncytial nests and a whorled pattern of cellular growth, which may calcify and appear as round, laminar structures called psammoma bodies (
    image 6
    ).
  • Clinical features:  Symptoms of meningioma depend on location of the tumor.  Because the tumors are very slow-growing and outside the brain parenchyma, patients are often asymptomatic with the tumor found incidentally on imaging.  However, patients can present with headaches, seizures, or focal neurological deficits depending on tumor location (eg, next to the cerebral cortex) and size.
  • Radiological features:  Meningiomas are typically well-circumscribed, round, extra-axial dural-based (attached to the outermost meningeal layer) lesions with homogeneous contrast enhancement on MRI (
    image 7
    ).  Calcification is a common feature that can be seen as a hyperdensity on noncontrast CT scan as well.


Management of meningiomas depends on size, location, and presence of symptoms.  Small (< 2 cm) asymptomatic tumors can be observed with serial imaging.  In symptomatic patients, complete surgical excision is typically curative.

Schwannomas



Schwannomas are benign tumors arising from Schwann cells, which produce the myelin sheath around peripheral nerves.  They can occur within the brain (intracranial) or involve cranial nerves.  Bilateral vestibular schwannomas are characteristic of NF2-related schwannomatosis (see article "NF2-related schwannomatosis" for more details).



  • Location:  Schwannomas classically occur at the cerebellopontine angle, though they can occur along any peripheral nerve.
  • Pathology:  Schwannomas are characterized by densely (Antoni type A) or loosely (Antoni type B) arranged spindle-shaped cells that may show nuclear palisading (ie, Verocay bodies) (
    image 8
    ).
  • Clinical features:  They typically present with focal neurological deficits related to the affected nerve.  For example, an acoustic schwannoma (vestibular schwannoma) can cause hearing loss, tinnitus, and imbalance due to compression of the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII) at the cerebellopontine angle.  Continued growth at this location can cause facial weakness due to compression of the facial nerve (CN VII).
  • Radiological features:  Schwannomas often appear as well-circumscribed, sometimes round lesions with contrast enhancement on MRI (
    image 9
    ).

Pituitary tumors



Pituitary tumors arise from the pituitary gland, a small structure at the base of the brain responsible for hormone production.  Pituitary tumors can be functioning (secreting hormones) or nonfunctioning.  These are discussed further in a separate dedicated article.

Primary CNS lymphoma



Primary CNS lymphoma (PCNSL) is a diffuse, large-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma of B-cell origin that is associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV).  It usually occurs in immunosuppressed patients (eg, organ transplant patients, patients with HIV/AIDs); however, PCNSL has been increasingly occurring in older patients (age >60) who are not immunocompromised.  Most commonly, it is seen as a late complication of HIV infection in patients with persistently depressed CD4 counts (< 50/mm3).



  • Location:  PCNSL can occur anywhere in the brain, although it typically arises in the cerebral hemispheres, often in the frontal lobes or in the periventricular white matter.  It can also occur in the eyes or in the CSF (eg, leptomeningeal).
  • Pathology:  Histologically, PCNSL is usually characterized by malignant B cells.
  • Clinical features:  PCNSL is a fast-growing tumor, with most patients exhibiting symptoms over days to weeks.  The presentation depends on the location of the tumor; patients often have focal neurological deficits or mental status changes.
  • Radiological features:  PCNSL usually appears as a solitary, irregular, ring-enhancing lesion on brain MRI. 


Brain biopsy is often required to make a definitive diagnosis.  The diagnosis can be supported by EBV DNA isolated in the cerebrospinal fluid, especially in patients with HIV.
